facts.text: Kanta Kumari, an orphan minor and niece of complainant PW1 Parmeshwar Pandey, was under his lawful guardianship and protection, residing with him since death of her parents.

At about 8 PM on February 14, 1965, two accused went to house of complainant and called Kanta Kumari out; she responded saying going for singing marriage songs, went with them and returned by midnight.
In morning of February 15, 1965, complainant found Kanta Kumari missing; on search, learnt she was seen at about 3 AM going in company of all five accused for Ganga Ashnan.
On evening of February 17, 1965, complainant met first accused Sia Devi and fifth accused; fifth accused informed that his paternal cousins accused Nos. 2 and 3 had taken Kanta Kumari away.
On February 18, 1965, Parmeshwar Pandey filed complaint before police alleging kidnapping of minor niece Kanta Kumari from his lawful guardianship by five accused.
All five accused charged under Section 363 IPC for kidnapping minor girl Kanta Kumari on February 15, 1965 from lawful guardianship of uncle Parmeshwar Pandey without consent.
Accused pleaded not guilty; stated falsely implicated due to long standing enmity; no niece Kanta Kumari; did not kidnap; she was major about 18 years old.

Trial by First Assistant Sessions Judge, Biharsharif; held Parmeshwar Pandey had niece Kanta Kumari living under his guardianship; she was 9 or 10 years old at time; accused Nos. 2-5 kidnapped her; convicted them under S.363 IPC, sentenced to RI 5 years + fine Rs.500 (default RI 6 months); acquitted accused No.1 Sia Devi.
Appellants filed Criminal Appeal No.453 of 1966 in Patna High Court on September 8, 1966 challenging findings and conviction.

On September 9, 1966, Patna High Court admitted appeal: 'This appeal will be heard. Issue notice. Pending hearing, appellants continue on bail to satisfaction of District Magistrate. Realisation of fine stayed.'

Appeal posted for hearing on May 10, 1968; neither appellants nor counsel appeared; High Court dismissed: 'No one appears to press this appeal. On perusal of the judgment under appeal, I find no merit in the case. It is accordingly dismissed.'
On May 10, 1968, appellants filed Criminal Miscellaneous Application No.556 of 1968 for restoration of appeal.
On July 12, 1968, High Court dismissed restoration application as no sufficient cause shown.
High Court dismissed application for certificate under Article 134(1)(c) Constitution along with condonation of delay on August 2, 1968.
Supreme Court granted special leave on December 11, 1968 against High Court order dated May 10, 1968.

legal_issues.text: Whether the judgment and order of the Patna High Court dated May 10, 1968, dismissing Criminal Appeal No.453 of 1966, is in conformity with Section 423 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
Whether the order pronounced by the High Court is a judgment as understood in law, containing points for determination, decision thereon and reasons.

petitioner_arguments.text: Disposal of appeal by High Court on May 10, 1968 contrary to Section 423 CrPC as it dismissed summarily after admitting and issuing notice; must look into entire record and give reasons irrespective of appearance.
High Court order not a judgment as it does not contain points for determination, decision thereon and reasons.
Finding on age of Kanta Kumari conjectural, not based on legal evidence.

respondent_arguments.text: Impugned order complies with Section 423 CrPC; High Court perused judgment under appeal and found no merit.
Section 367 CrPC relating to contents of judgment does not apply to High Court; relies on Section 424 CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: Under Section 421 CrPC, appeal can be summarily dismissed after perusing petition and copy of judgment if no sufficient ground for interference; but here High Court admitted appeal on Sep 9, 1966, issued notice per Section 422, so proceeded to Section 423 stage requiring perusal of record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Once appeal admitted and notice issued, High Court must send for and peruse record before disposal, even if no appearance.

court_reasoning.text: Section 423 mandates sending for record if not already in court, peruse it, hear if appear, then dispose; cannot dismiss for default; must consider on merits after perusing record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for non-appearance; disposal must be on merits after perusal of record.

court_reasoning.text: High Court order only mentions perusal of judgment under appeal, no indication of perusing record sent for; does not show application of judicial mind to record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No indication High Court perused record as required; order not in conformity with Section 423.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Sankatha Singh as not dealing with High Court appellate order under Section 423.

holdings.text: High Court order dated May 10, 1968 not in conformity with Section 423 CrPC as no perusal of record indicated; must be set aside.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mushtak Hussein v. The State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Summary dismissal under S.421 requires reasons if substantial point raised.

precedents_cited.case_name: Govinda Kadtuji Kadam v. The State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Reiterates need for indication of views on arguable points in summary dismissal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Challappa Ramaswami v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Recent decision on need for indication in summary rejections.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sankatha Singh v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Dealt with Sessions Judge's order, not High Court under S.423; no support for respondent.

statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of kidnapping minor from lawful guardianship

statutes_cited.relevance: Powers and procedure for appellate courts in criminal appeals; requirement to peruse record before disposal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the Patna High Court order dated May 10, 1968 dismissing the criminal appeal for non-appearance without perusing the record as required under Section 423 CrPC.

key_quotes.text: "The short question that arises in this appeal... is whether the judgment and order of the Patna High Court dated May 10, 1968... are in conformity with Section 423 of the Code of Criminal Procedure."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A reading of Section 423 makes it clear that a criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for default of appearance of the appellants or their counsel."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.key_observation: Central holding on mandatory consideration on merits.

key_quotes.text: "There must be a clear indication in the judgment or order of the Appellate Court that it has applied its judicial mind to the particular appeal... after perusing the record."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "No one appears to press this appeal. On perusal of the judgment under appeal, I find no merit in the case. It is accordingly dismissed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: The impugned High Court order held defective.
